awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Sean P. Howe is "Overconvergent Automorphic Forms and the p-Adic Langlands Program." The host institution for the fellowship is Stanford University, and the sponsoring scientist is Brian Conrad.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on an area of mathematics that applies tools from geometry (like curvature and distance) and harmonic analysis (the study of waves, like ocean waves, sound waves and light waves) to help us understand the symmetries of numbers (such as Gauss's quadratic reciprocity law, an elementary arithmetic statement relating square numbers and prime numbers).  

The main mathematical object in this work is called a perfectoid space. These live in a world of geometry called p-adic geometry where our regular notion of distance is replaced with a much stranger notion adapted to studying divisibility by a prime number p. The objects in this world cannot be visualized easily, but nonetheless many of the same geometric properties like distance and curvature make good sense. Perfectoid spaces ``look" in some ways like a fractal (such as the Cantor middle thirds set), but they have important formal properties that are very close to those of the Euclidean plane. They were introduced by Peter Scholze less than 10 years ago, and provide the right mathematical language to make sense of many classical geometric constructions that previously had no reasonable analog in the p-adic world -- in particular, this includes some important constructions in the field of algebraic topology, which studies how shapes behave when you are allowed to squish and squeeze (but not rip!) them. 

The work supported by this grant used these new geometric constructions to establish striking connections between objects built from symmetries of negatively curved space (modular forms) and objects that live purely in the world of p-adic geometry. These connections, for example, let us deduce new  properties of objects describing classical geometries (important, e.g., in physics) by exploiting simple computations in the p-adic world (which reduce essentially to computations with finite sets!).  

In addition to the mathematical contributions, the PI also engaged in significant outreach work while supported by this grant. In particular, he ran two online summer introduction to research in mathematics programs for beginning undergraduates, with an emphasis on participation from underrepresented groups. He also participated in outreach to highschool students, and mentored undergraduate research projects.
